docs.lead_paragraph: SCHOOL enrollments are burgeoning around the state, and cities and towns are scrambling to find space in which to put all these students. Some are reopening long-closed schools; others are building new ones. In Stamford, officials are trying something different. With high school enrollment expected to jump in the city by about 1,000 over the next six years, officials have their eyes on a school building at Scalzi Park that has room for about 800 students. The site would be perfect. The problem is, there is already a high school there. The school, J. M. Wright Regional Vocational Technical School, is run by the state, and if Stamford takes the building, its 459 students would have to find another place to go.
docs.abstract: Article on controversial decision by school officials in Stamford, Conn, to ask state to close J M Wright Regional Vocational Technical School in Scalzi Park in order to reopen it as regular high school; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: SUPPOSE there were a way to give police officers a psychological test to determine if they were racially biased and a scan to determine where in the brain the bias resided? Suppose there were a way to eliminate the bias altogether? At a time when the country is reacting to the assault on Abner Louima and the killing of Amadou Diallo, Stanley Pottinger raises the issue in his novel released this month, ''A Slow Burning'' (Dutton).
docs.abstract: Interview with Stanley Pottinger on his new suspense novel, A Slow Burning, in which he raises issue of whether the brain could be reprogrammed to rid it of bias; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Unlocking the Truth, a trio of middle-schoolers who make blunt rock music, defies expectations as it gets closer to making its metal dreams come true.
docs.abstract: Brooklyn heavy metal band Unlocking the Truth is comprised of middle-schoolers, but members Alec Atkins, Malcolm Brickhouse and Jarad Dawkins are clear about their dedication to heavy music and rejection of boy band aesthetic aimed at kid audiences; band has defied expectations in number of ways, from their choice of musical influences to their breakaway success.

docs.lead_paragraph: I promised my roommates that I would get this all down one day. I promised them I would finally tell the world: I cry in bathrooms. We all cried in bathrooms. Like lost puppies in a colossal sea of college-level sameness, we locked ourselves in quasi-private bathroom stalls and cried. There were the ones in Doe, (there were always staff coming in and out, fist-shake!) and the one in Gianinni Hall where I splotchily ran into an economic advisor to the World Bank. Or how about the International and Area Studies building, a bathroom that looked more like a shabby country-club locker room, with the faux hospitality of scented hand lotion and tampax. All of these and more, and I got to know pretty seriously what if feels like to be a disillusioned college student.
